author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Headaches
content: Dear momgonzo4,  Headaches have many reasons.   If you think that the headaches are caused by a brain tumour, there is one important symptom missing in the triad of increased intracranial pressure. This symptom is projectile vomiting without being preceded by nausea. The other 2 symptoms that you mentioned were headaches and blurred vision.  The blurred vision and headaches can be caused by problems with vision. If you are becoming short sighted and you are not wearing prescription glasses, you can have blurred vision and headaches secondary to that as the lens of the eye tries to compensate and then becomes stressed and the stress causes the headache.  If you work on a computer all day long and you are sitting in an uncorrect posture, this will cause stress on the muscles of the back of your neck and shoulders and this will give rise to a headache.  Headaches can be caused by increased blood pressure, so, you have to have your blood pressure measured.  If you are concerned that your headaches are caused by a brain tumour, you should have a physical examination by your doctor and then he can decide whether or not a ct scan of the head is warranted.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male

content: The salty taste you are experiencing could be due to many causes. It could be that you are dehydrated especially if you are taking a medicine such as a diuretic, or drinking too much cafienated drinks (coffee, coke.. etc). Alcohol also has diuretic properties.  Other causes include infection in the mucosa of the mouth or a post-nasal drip due to chronic sinusitis. If you have an increased production of tears this could be a very rare cause. An even rarer cause is due to brain lesions such as a new epileptic lesion, brain tumor or a migraine.  If you are not dehydrated and do not have sinusitis then you should seek an appointment with your physician.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello again, I am glad you saw a neurologist. In your last post I gave you a list of possibilities for the salty taste in your mouth which included the possibility of a brain tumor. Your neurologist has had a better chance to evaluate you since he has assessed you in person. He would be able to weigh out all the options and consider the likelyhood of one of them more than the other. However, and from a purely speculative point of view, I think your neurologist is mainly ruling out the most dangerous cause (brain tumor) before he considers other less dangerous (and more common) causes of your symptoms.  I would advise you not to worry about the scan its just part of the medical diagnostic process.  If it were a brain tumor which type would it be? I suspect what you mean is would it be benign or malignant? That would be hard to tell even for your neurologist at any point. If it were a brain tumor then your age could hint at a possible malignant lesion. However, certain details would make us suspect a benign tumor: the long duration of your symptoms (months) is more common with benign lesions. Indeed the symptoms themselves, are more common with a steadily growing tumor than a malignant one. However you should know that with brain tumors in particular the spectrum between benign and malignant types is a rather continuous one (there are so many types that behave at varying degrees of aggressiveness ranging from purely benign to low malignant potential to agressive).  Only a biopsy would determine the true nature of a brain tumor and its behaviour. Again, I remind you to not worry!  Please post the results of your scan to this topic.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hi psmadden,  Calcification of in the brain could be a million things. From tumors, to vascular anomalies to even metabolic diseases. The distribution of calcification is very important at determining its source. If its located in one area it may suggest a tumor. If its located in the course of known vessels that may suggest a vascular malformation. If its widely distributed it may be a metabolic disease.  Physiological calcification is seen in the pineal gland and choroid plexus from the age of approximately 8 to 10 years.  Pathological calcification may be seen in the meninges (lining of the brain), brain parenchyma (brain substance), including the basal ganglia (an area in the center of the brain), and in the cerebral vasculature. Calcification may also be seen in intracranial tumours such as craniopharyngioma and in areas of necrosis following infection, haemorrhage, or infarction. Gyriform calcification is seen in neuroectodermal dysplasias such as Sturge Weber syndrome. Dural calcification is seen in chronic subdural haematoma and in Gorlin's syndrome. Extensive early calcification may be seen in the choroid plexus in patients with neurofibromatosis.   CT is the most sensitive means of detection of intracranial calcification. MRI is less sensitive to the detection of intracranial calcification than CT.  Can you tell us what the report says about the distribution?  It may still be that the calcification is urelated to your symptoms and just something discovered along the way.  Best regards,

From about 8 months ago until now, i began noticing the feelings getting stronger, more frequent, sometimes slight pain, especially when i lay down or exercise, and feels like its affecting also the right and left portions of the back of my head. It feels like tension in the back of my brain.. no throbbing, just tension. I notice the feelings several times a day, at least 4 or 5 times a day, and sometimes noticable for hours at a time. Twice though, i felt severe tension and moderate pain, felt like i was going to pass out or the back of my head was going to explode. I also notice slight visual disturbance (blurred vision, trouble focusing, "floaters" and static things.. almost every time i look up into the sky on a sunny day, it looks like thousands of specks floating around in all directions that resemble fireworks exploding), also some speech impairment, confusion, difficulty in understanding what people are saying, slow brain thoughts, dyslexic type symptoms.. whenever i try to talk, i get my words mixed up, and often find myself repeating myself in mid sentence, and saying things i didnt mean to say or getting myself mixed up and end up making no sense.  Anyhow,i'm a 20 year old male,  those are my symptoms, and i'd greatly appreciate any info. Oh yeah, and the reason why i havnt seen a professional: I hardly ever leave my house, and when i do, my parents know exactly where im going, and i am wanting to wait until i get a car and go visit a professional without having to risk my privacy. I'd like to tackle this head on with my familys support, but i would like to have an experts opinion on my situation so i know what to expect so i can approach this subject with my parents appropiatly. Sorry for the long message, Thanks for taking the time to look at it.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Brain
content: Matt2123,  Thanks for posting your question at The Doctor's Lounge.   First, let me start by stating that any infomation provided here does not and should not replace your seeing a doctor to evaluate and examine you for the problems you report.  Such problems are statistically more likely to not be related to a brain tumor than they are to be related to such.  Nevertheless, the problems you describe have been present for a while and are causing you problems.  Thus, they should be checked out by your family doctor.  Sometimes, a referral is made to a Neurologist for further evaluation.  Your problems make me think of migraine type processes.  I cannot state that they represent a brain tumor.   I would recommend that you do see your family doctor for further evaluation.  It would not be an unreasonable idea to have a brain scan, such as a CAT scan or an MRI, as part of the evaluation.  One could also consider trying migraine treatments the next time that you get the problems to see if such treatments work.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Brain sounds
content: XUT67,  I am not aware that any problem inside the brain, including brain tumors, causes sounds unless the part of the brain dealing with auditory functions is affected.  Perhaps ypu are hearing some changes with your sinues affecting the ears.  It is unlikely that there is a barin tumor.  However, since this problem is bothering you and is a source of concern for you, then I would recommend that you see your physician to be evaluated, including an ear examination.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Li-Fraumeni syndroime
content: My apologies for the delay in answering your question.  The Li-Fraumeni syndrome is one of many discovered hereditary cancer syndromes.  It does not define just one type of cancer, but a cluster of various cancers seen together or in a family.  Just because one family member has the Li-Fraumeni syndrome does not imply that all family members will have it or develop a cancer.  It does increase the likelihood that family members will have the syndrome, however.  Furthermore, many cancers are common, especially in an aging population.  So-called "family" histories of cancers are not true hereditary syndromes, but rather the presence of common cancers in different family members at risk for such common cancers.  Physicians should maintain a clinical concern for hereditary cancer syndromes in the appropriate context.  There are genetic tests that can be done to evaluate the Li-Fraumeni syndrome.  Such tests should be done only at reputable cancer genetic centers, where counseling about the test can be undertaken and reliable results obtained.  No cancer genetic testing is 100% foolproof.  In addition, there are probably countless other hereditary cancer syndromes and gene changes present that we as physicians do not know because they have yet to be discovered or identified.  Hereditary syndromes or diseases can "skip" a generation, depending upon the complexities of their transmission from one generation to the next.  Some people have the "full blown" hereditary syndrome whereas others just have a "trait" and are not affected by the associated cancers or diseases.  In addition, there is a term called "penetrance" which, simply stated, defines the characteristics of a hereditary gene process with regard to its becoming clinically apparent or "silent".  A gene that has a high penetrance almost always results in a clinicallly apparent outcome, whereas a gene with a low penetrance is usually not associated with a clinically apparent outcome.  In order to better understand the complexities of cancer genetics, it is always best to under go hereditary cancer genetic testing under the care of a trained cancer geneticist who can individualize such testing on a person to person or a family to family basis.
